Long live the rising generation ... Long live!
A generation of an enduring people ... Long live!
Long may it live, building and struggling. Long may it live, with its eternal struggle.
One man. One principle.
Long live our revolution's generation - Long live!
Wardah:
Long live the soldier on the day he smashed the thorn of colonialism.
The title of revolutionary victory was in every free country.
And we heard him saying it with full force
in the name of a proud nation's principles:
"I am a line of offense & defense. I am a symbol of peace and conflict.
I sacrifice my soul, and I live in times of victory as a brave hero"
Salute with me. Say with me.
Long live the Arab soldier - Long live!
Najat As-Saghira:
Long live the farmer on the day his eyes felt the heat of the sun.
It spread its light, and the plants grew as he protected them.
And we heard him saying it with full force:
"(This is) the land of my children, and it has returned to me!
They deprived us for years and years. And thought the people were asleep.
And we came out on them one day, and repaid the rights of millions."
Salute with me, say with me
Long live the farmer of the revolution - Long live!
Abd El-Halim Hafez:
Long live the arts as a nation's civilisation, built by the artist.
He narrates its story in a melody, a word,
an image, with soul and with faith.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"My country's glory is an oath borne upon me.
My heart and my soul are owned by my art, and both are, to my country, a gift."
Salute with me, Say with me
Long live art as a message - Long live!
Fayza Ahmad:
Long live the worker that day he thought to build for his country a home.
In it are chimneys, spurting out from it flames and light and fire.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"This is my production, and what my hand has made.
We have achieved with the aid of God, for the people their prayer and their hopes.
And goodness has increased and overflowed, and what has overflowed we exported."
Say with me, Salute with me.
Long live, Long live, the worker, Long live!
Shadia:
Long live the student that day he sought knowledge - a book and a weapon.
He knew that knowledge was a means by which every success can be reached.
And we heard him say it with full force,
in high school and in college:
"Knowledge is a mighty weapon, it turns our night into day,
it travels towards light by light, and faces fire with fire."
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live the rising generation - Long live!
Abd El-Wahaab:
Long live all the Arab people, a people of peace & security
Long live the Arab consciousness, a revolution in every place.
A rebellious revolution for freedom.
It jumped up and called for nationalism.
We answered your call, O Gamal. Our hands in yours, O Gamal.
And we ascended with you, O Gamal. We build with you, O Gamal.
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live Abd El-Nasser - Long live!

And we came out on them one day, and repaid the rights of millions."
Salute with me, say with me
Long live the farmer of the revolution - Long live!
Abd El-Halim Hafez:
Long live the arts as a nation's civilisation, built by the artist.
He narrates its story in a melody, a word,
an image, with soul and with faith.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"My country's glory is an oath borne upon me.
My heart and my soul are owned by my art, and both are, to my country, a gift."
Salute with me, Say with me
Long live art as a message - Long live!
Fayza Ahmad:
Long live the worker that day he thought to build for his country a home.
In it are chimneys, spurting out from it flames and light and fire.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"This is my production, and what my hand has made.
We have achieved with the aid of God, for the people their prayer and their hopes.
And goodness has increased and overflowed, and what has overflowed we exported."
Say with me, Salute with me.
Long live, Long live, the worker, Long live!
Shadia:
Long live the student that day he sought knowledge - a book and a weapon.
He knew that knowledge was a means by which every success can be reached.
And we heard him say it with full force,
in high school and in college:
"Knowledge is a mighty weapon, it turns our night into day,
it travels towards light by light, and faces fire with fire."
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live the rising generation - Long live!
Abd El-Wahaab:
Long live all the Arab people, a people of peace & security
Long live the Arab consciousness, a revolution in every place.
A rebellious revolution for freedom.
It jumped up and called for nationalism.
We answered your call, O Gamal. Our hands in yours, O Gamal.
And we ascended with you, O Gamal. We build with you, O Gamal.
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live Abd El-Nasser - Long live!

And his wife endured these scourges.
His wife was of a noble lineage.

Oh, Job! We thought it all to finish in the first year.
In the second year she kept enduring your misery.
In the third year, O, Job, you became so exhausted and ill.
The noble honor is not proof against schadenfreude.
In the forth year you have been let down by the folk of your town.
They said: "Take him and go away, dearest!".
She said: "O, you haters! There is no need for bashing.
How can one escape from shame if he bought1 his own flesh?"
She said: "O, you haters! There is no need for bashing.
Wait for night to pass
and we will be leaving in the morning"
She walked for a day, for two, for three,
For four days, enduring hunger. But Na'saa was patient.

In front of which was a spring of pure, sweet water.
Na'saa left Job there and headed toward the town.
And now she is about to go begging
in wealthy towns.2

Long live the rising generation ... Long live!
A generation of an enduring people ... Long live!
Long may it live, building and struggling. Long may it live, with its eternal struggle.
One man. One principle.
Long live our revolution's generation - Long live!
Wardah:
Long live the soldier on the day he smashed the thorn of colonialism.
The title of revolutionary victory was in every free country.
And we heard him saying it with full force
in the name of a proud nation's principles:
"I am a line of offense & defense. I am a symbol of peace and conflict.
I sacrifice my soul, and I live in times of victory as a brave hero"
Salute with me. Say with me.
Long live the Arab soldier - Long live!
Najat As-Saghira:
Long live the farmer on the day his eyes felt the heat of the sun.
It spread its light, and the plants grew as he protected them.
And we heard him saying it with full force:
"(This is) the land of my children, and it has returned to me!
They deprived us for years and years. And thought the people were asleep.
And we came out on them one day, and repaid the rights of millions."
Salute with me, say with me
Long live the farmer of the revolution - Long live!
Abd El-Halim Hafez:
Long live the arts as a nation's civilisation, built by the artist.
He narrates its story in a melody, a word,
an image, with soul and with faith.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"My country's glory is an oath borne upon me.
My heart and my soul are owned by my art, and both are, to my country, a gift."
Salute with me, Say with me
Long live art as a message - Long live!
Fayza Ahmad:
Long live the worker that day he thought to build for his country a home.
In it are chimneys, spurting out from it flames and light and fire.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"This is my production, and what my hand has made.
We have achieved with the aid of God, for the people their prayer and their hopes.
And goodness has increased and overflowed, and what has overflowed we exported."
Say with me, Salute with me.
Long live, Long live, the worker, Long live!
Shadia:
Long live the student that day he sought knowledge - a book and a weapon.
He knew that knowledge was a means by which every success can be reached.
And we heard him say it with full force,
in high school and in college:
"Knowledge is a mighty weapon, it turns our night into day,
it travels towards light by light, and faces fire with fire."
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live the rising generation - Long live!
Abd El-Wahaab:
Long live all the Arab people, a people of peace & security
Long live the Arab consciousness, a revolution in every place.
A rebellious revolution for freedom.
It jumped up and called for nationalism.
We answered your call, O Gamal. Our hands in yours, O Gamal.
And we ascended with you, O Gamal. We build with you, O Gamal.
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live Abd El-Nasser - Long live!

Qais: Layla!
(Al-Mahdi coming out of the tent) =
Who is the shouting caller? Is it Qais I see?
Why do you remain standing whilst the men have gone?
Qais: (in embarrassment)
I was not, O uncle, amongst them
Al-Mahdi: (surprised)
Where were you, then?
Qais:
In our home until our home ran out of fire.
Whatever our place had of plentiful firewood
the winds finished it, and so did the guest and the neighbour.
Al-Mahdi: (calling)
Layla! Wait, Qais. Layla!
Layla: from the depths of the tent
What is the matter, father?
Al-Mahdi:
This is your cousin, there is no fire in their home.
(Layla appears from the entrance of the tent)
Layla:
Qais, my cousin, is with us! O welcome, O welcome!
Qais:
May you be blessed, O Layla, with life and fulfill your wishes.
Layla: (calling her servant lady whilst her father disappears into the tent)
.. Afraa! ...
Afraa: (responding to the call of her mistress) - My lady.
Layla:
Come, let us do our duty that we must.
Take a vessel and fill it for my cousin with firewood.
Afraa comes out and follows Layla
Qais:
By my soul is Layla, she met a need that came upon me,
why should she not meet for my heart its many needs?
How often have I come to Layla with invented reasons,
how many were they - my reasons and my purposes!
(Layla enters)
Layla: Qais,
Qais: Layla is by my side! if so, then everything (in the world) is here!
Layla: It did well, this hour that has brought us together, (it is) greater than all of one's life.
Qais: Are you serious?
Layla: my heart is not iron or stone.
You have a heart so ask it, O Qais, and it will inform you of the truth.
I have endured in love above that which humans can endure.
Qais: I do not know, my Layla, how I can complain and explode?
Do I explain all of my love & longing or do I say of it little?
Layla: Tell me, Qais, what need do you have of the desert?
You have poems about it that have surpassed it and reached the cities.
Have you abandoned us and fallen in love with the other gazelles (beauties)?
Qais: Layla, you are envious of the gazelles and the gazelles of you are not envious.
You are not like the (normal) young beauties, no, nor is the desert moon like any moon.
Layla: (she sees the fire almost reaching Qais's sleeve)
Oh my, what do I see?!
Qais: Layla!
Layla:
Beware!
Qais: (doesn't care about anything except what he was discussing)
Perhaps (there was) a sunrise that I once asked if you had breathed into it before daybreak,
And a wind I thought had dragged the fragrant tail (of your garment),
And a gazelle whose eyelids had stolen your beautiful eyes.
Al-Mahdi: Leave, Qais, Leave! Did you come seeking fire
or to set our house on fire, I wonder?!
Qais:
The night has calmed until my poetry & love erupted ... and what is the desert except the night, poetry and love?
I have filled the skies of the desert with love, and its earth ... and I carried that love alone, O Lord!
Love carried me to Layla's house... and but my verses of poetry there was no guide or companion.
And my tent is only a step away from her's, but neither did being her neighbour satisfy me nor her proximity.
When my heart floats around her, its longing goes mad ... like a severe thirst exacerbated by (seeing) the fresh spring.
It yearns if she departs, and craves if she approaches .... O my heart! It so does yearn & crave!

Long live the rising generation ... Long live!
A generation of an enduring people ... Long live!
Long may it live, building and struggling. Long may it live, with its eternal struggle.
One man. One principle.
Long live our revolution's generation - Long live!
Wardah:
Long live the soldier on the day he smashed the thorn of colonialism.
The title of revolutionary victory was in every free country.
And we heard him saying it with full force
in the name of a proud nation's principles:
"I am a line of offense & defense. I am a symbol of peace and conflict.
I sacrifice my soul, and I live in times of victory as a brave hero"
Salute with me. Say with me.
Long live the Arab soldier - Long live!
Najat As-Saghira:
Long live the farmer on the day his eyes felt the heat of the sun.
It spread its light, and the plants grew as he protected them.
And we heard him saying it with full force:
"(This is) the land of my children, and it has returned to me!
They deprived us for years and years. And thought the people were asleep.
And we came out on them one day, and repaid the rights of millions."
Salute with me, say with me
Long live the farmer of the revolution - Long live!
Abd El-Halim Hafez:
Long live the arts as a nation's civilisation, built by the artist.
He narrates its story in a melody, a word,
an image, with soul and with faith.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"My country's glory is an oath borne upon me.
My heart and my soul are owned by my art, and both are, to my country, a gift."
Salute with me, Say with me
Long live art as a message - Long live!
Fayza Ahmad:
Long live the worker that day he thought to build for his country a home.
In it are chimneys, spurting out from it flames and light and fire.
And we heard him say it with full force:
"This is my production, and what my hand has made.
We have achieved with the aid of God, for the people their prayer and their hopes.
And goodness has increased and overflowed, and what has overflowed we exported."
Say with me, Salute with me.
Long live, Long live, the worker, Long live!
Shadia:
Long live the student that day he sought knowledge - a book and a weapon.
He knew that knowledge was a means by which every success can be reached.
And we heard him say it with full force,
in high school and in college:
"Knowledge is a mighty weapon, it turns our night into day,
it travels towards light by light, and faces fire with fire."
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live the rising generation - Long live!
Abd El-Wahaab:
Long live all the Arab people, a people of peace & security
Long live the Arab consciousness, a revolution in every place.
A rebellious revolution for freedom.
It jumped up and called for nationalism.
We answered your call, O Gamal. Our hands in yours, O Gamal.
And we ascended with you, O Gamal. We build with you, O Gamal.
Salute with me, say with me.
Long live Abd El-Nasser - Long live!
